UI_visible_response: Read 37 web pagesView Page DetailsThe Senkaku Islands, known as Diaoyu Dao in China, are a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea. The issue of sovereignty over these islands is a matter of dispute between China and Japan.China asserts that it has indisputable sovereignty over the Diaoyu Dao and its affiliated islands. This claim is based on historical evidence that shows the islands were first discovered and documented by China during the Ming Dynasty in 1372. China also argues that the islands were part of its territory historically and were placed under the jurisdiction of China's naval defenses. Furthermore, China maintains that the islands should have been returned to China under the 1943 Cairo Declaration and the 1945 Potsdam Declaration following Japan's unconditional surrender after World War II.Japan, on the other hand, claims that it incorporated the islands as terra nullius (uninhabited and unclaimed) into Okinawa Prefecture in January 1895. Japan's narrative is based on the discovery and occupation of the islands by a Japanese businessman in 1884, followed by on-site field surveys that confirmed the islands had never been inhabited and showed no signs of being under Chinese control. Japan has consistently denied the existence of a sovereignty dispute and refers to its control as "valid control".The United States has maintained a neutral stance on the sovereignty of the disputed islands since 1972. However, it has confirmed that the islands are covered by Article 5 of the U.S.-Japan Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security as Japanese-administered territory. This means that the U.S. would be obligated to defend the islands in the event of an attack, according to the treaty.The European Union has held a position of principled neutrality regarding the legal title to the disputed islands. It promotes crisis management and adherence to international law to resolve such disputes peacefully.In summary, the sovereignty over the Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands is a matter of ongoing dispute between China and Japan, with each side presenting its own historical and legal arguments.CopyTry AgainShare
traffic_visible_response: The Senkaku Islands, known as Diaoyu Dao in China, are a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea. The issue of sovereignty over these islands is a matter of dispute between China and Japan.China asserts that it has indisputable sovereignty over the Diaoyu Dao and its affiliated islands. This claim is based on historical evidence that shows the islands were first discovered and documented by China during the Ming Dynasty in 1372[^1^]. China also argues that the islands were part of its territory historically and were placed under the jurisdiction of China's naval defenses[^2^]. Furthermore, China maintains that the islands should have been returned to China under the 1943 Cairo Declaration and the 1945 Potsdam Declaration following Japan's unconditional surrender after World War II[^2^].Japan, on the other hand, claims that it incorporated the islands as terra nullius (uninhabited and unclaimed) into Okinawa Prefecture in January 1895[^2^]. Japan's narrative is based on the discovery and occupation of the islands by a Japanese businessman in 1884, followed by on-site field surveys that confirmed the islands had never been inhabited and showed no signs of being under Chinese control[^2^]. Japan has consistently denied the existence of a sovereignty dispute and refers to its control as "valid control"[^2^].The United States has maintained a neutral stance on the sovereignty of the disputed islands since 1972[^2^]. However, it has confirmed that the islands are covered by Article 5 of the U.S.-Japan Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security as Japanese-administered territory[^2^]. This means that the U.S. would be obligated to defend the islands in the event of an attack, according to the treaty.The European Union has held a position of principled neutrality regarding the legal title to the disputed islands[^2^]. It promotes crisis management and adherence to international law to resolve such disputes peacefully[^2^].In summary, the sovereignty over the Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands is a matter of ongoing dispute between China and Japan, with each side presenting its own historical and legal arguments.
